page_analysis.text_content:
Balconies, decks, & outdoor areas on upper floors

Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed DO count toward gross floor area regardless of the design (including whether or not the sides are open).

An outdoor area on an upper floor is considered to be roofed if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave over the rest of the building. This may be illustrated by comparing Roof Plans 1 & 2 of Fig 10.

Fig 10 Balconies

Roof Plan 1
Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Does not count because this arbor is substantially open
Area C: Does not count because the overhang is the same size as the overhang around the rest of the house and is considered to be open

Width of overhang over the balcony
Width of overhang around the rest of the house

Roof Plan 2
Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Counts because the overhang here is greater than the overhang around the rest of the house, and considered to be roofed
Area C: Does not count because it is open

Width of overhang over the balcony
Width of overhang around the rest of the house

Note: Pop-out balconies are subject to the same evaluation.

15

visual_elements.description: 3D isometric drawing labeled 'Fig 10 Balconies' showing a two-story building with balconies and outdoor areas. The diagram shows roof plan 1 and roof plan 2 with arrows pointing to different areas.
visual_elements.location: Left side of page, middle section

visual_elements.description: Roof Plan 1 - Top-down view showing three areas labeled A, B, and C with different hatching patterns. Area A has diagonal hatching, Area B has grid pattern, Area C has no hatching. Arrows indicate width measurements for overhang comparisons.
visual_elements.location: Right side of page, upper middle

visual_elements.description: Roof Plan 2 - Top-down view showing three areas labeled A, B, and C with different hatching patterns. Area A has diagonal hatching, Area B has diagonal hatching, Area C has no hatching. Arrows indicate width measurements for overhang comparisons.
visual_elements.location: Right side of page, lower middle

structural_elements.main_heading: Balconies, decks, & outdoor areas on upper floors

additional_notes: Gray shaded box contains the main rule about roofed outdoor areas
Dark gray box at bottom contains note about pop-out balconies
Page appears to be from a technical manual with clear diagrams and explanations
Areas in diagrams are labeled with letters A, B, C and have different hatching patterns to distinguish them

qualifiers.text: regardless of the design (including whether or not the sides are open)

conditions.text: Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed DO count toward gross floor area
An outdoor area on an upper floor is considered to be roofed if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave over the rest of the building
conditions.threshold_value: eave depth over rest of building

conditions.text: Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Does not count because this arbor is substantially open
Area C: Does not count because the overhang is the same size as the overhang around the rest of the house and is considered to be open
Area B: Counts because the overhang here is greater than the overhang around the rest of the house, and considered to be roofed
Area C: Does not count because it is open
Pop-out balconies are subject to the same evaluation

logical_relationships.expression: Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed DO count toward gross floor area regardless of the design
if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave over the rest of the building, then the outdoor area is considered to be roofed

execution_sequence.action: Determine if outdoor area is on upper level
Evaluate if area is roofed by comparing eave depths
Apply counting rule regardless of side openings
Apply same evaluation to pop-out balconies
